climbs.name: West Nile
climbs.fa: Bill Cramer, Kevin Keith, Josh Bradley, 2004

content.description: Technical edging is the definition of this route, follow the bolts straight up starting to the right of the offwidth's start. Crux is going through the 3-4bolts and slightly insecure topout. Well protected though in the bolted section.
content.protection: There are 5 bolts, 1 at the start of the climb and the other 4 on the upper face. Bolted anchor at the top. Gear would be nice to protect the last moves over the darker colored bulge, above the first bolt. Pro would be in 0.75C4 range.
content.location: Route starts down and right of the bolt that is to the right of the Offwidth start, and about 15' up. Rap down when at the top.

climbs.name: The Quarterback Sneak
climbs.fa: Kevin Keith, Bill Cramer et al

content.description: Just left of Last Man Standing, climb a small crack in a corner to gain a prominent ledge. Scramble onto a little pinnacle and step over to the wall. Climb steep face past bolts and gear to reach the anchor. The crux is protected by a small gray and or blue C-4 cam.Â
content.location: Park at at the Flume Trail head on Granite Dells Rd and follow the trail along Granite Creek to the Dam. The Dam Wall is across a little steel bridge. The Quarterback Sneak is the partially bolted line just left of the obvious chimney.

content.description: Follow the crack directly to the left of the face for West Nile. Toward the top stay on the left of the vertical block separated from the face by a smaller crack. The chimney here is pretty narrow. Crux is probably somewhere on the bottom half of it
content.protection: Smaller pieces, .5 to 2 or so. Anchor at two bolts on a left facing small block on the right side near the top of the formation
content.location: Left of the face of West Nile. Approximately at the middle of the formation if looking at it from the creek

content.description: This route is left of the Dam Crack. Climb the face just right of the choked chimney with a mass of wire in it. The face is the crux with 3 bolts protecting the moves. At 3rd bolt step left and stem to a good stance across the chimney. Continue in beautiful crack that moves through various sizes from fist to fingers eventually merging with the best part of The Dam Crack near the top. I have placed two glue-ins at the top.
content.protection: Bolts and a standard rack with an optional #4 Camalot for the top. Not necessary but makes the last moves feel good.
content.location: The route is the obvious bolted line left of the Dam Crack.

content.description: The most aesthetic crack on this portion of the wall closest to the dam. This is one of the best cracks at the Dells. climb the crack until it peters out and then make a couple of slabby moves to the top. Setting up an anchor is a little bit tough, and not all that solid but marginal.
content.protection: single rack hands to fingers size pieces

content.description: This is the most prominent wall one sees once they enter the region below the dam. There are handful of quality routes here, just be wary of loose rock.
